        2015-12-10 Vatican Radio 

 (Vatican Radio) The Vatican’s Commission for Religious Relations with Jews has released a new document exploring the unresolved theological questions at the heart of Christian-Jewish dialogue. 

 The new document, entitled ‘The Gifts and Calling of God are irrevocable’, marks the 50th anniversary of the ground-breaking declaration ‘Nostra Aetate’. It was presented at a press conference in the Vatican on Thursday, by Cardinal Kurt Koch, Fr Norbert Hofmann of the Vatican Commission, together with two Jewish representatives, Rabbi David Rosen, International Director of Interreligious Affairs for the American Jewish Committee, and Dr Ed Kessler, founding director of the Cambridge Woolf Institute. 

 Please find below the full text of the document "The Gifts and Calling of God are irrevocable" 

 COMMISSION FOR RELIGIOUS RELATIONS WITH THE JEWS 

 “THE GIFTS AND THE CALLING OF GOD ARE IRREVOCABLE” (Rom 11:29) 

 A REFLECTION ON THEOLOGICAL QUESTIONS PERTAINING TO CATHOLIC-JEWISH RELATIONS ON THE OCCASION OF THE 50TH ANNIVERSARY OF “NOSTRA AETATE” (NO.4) 

 INDEX 

 A brief history of the impact of “Nostra aetate” (No.4) over the last 50 years 

 The special theological status of Jewish-Catholic dialogue 

 Revelation in history as ‘Word of God’ in Judaism and Christianity 

 The relationship between the Old and New Testament and the Old and New Covenant 

 5. The universality of salvation in Jesus Christ and God’s unrevoked covenant with Israel 

 The Church’s mandate to evangelize in relation to Judaism 

 The goals of dialogue with Judaism 

 PREFACE 

 Fifty years ago, the declaration “Nostra aetate ” of the Second Vatican Council was promulgated. Its fourth article presents the relationship between the Catholic Church and the Jewish people in a new theological framework. The following reflections aim at looking back with gratitude on all that has been achieved over the last decades in the Jewish-Catholic relationship, providing at the same time a new stimulus for the future. Stressing once again the unique status of this relationship within the wider ambit of interreligious dialogue, theological questions are further discussed, such as the relevance of revelation, the relationship between the Old and the New Covenant, the relationship between the universality of salvation in Jesus Christ and the affirmation that the covenant of God with Israel has never been revoked, and the Church’s mandate to evangelize in relation to Judaism. This document presents Catholic reflections on these questions, placing them in a theological context, in order that their significance may be deepened for members of both faith traditions. The text is not a magisterial document or doctrinal teaching of the Catholic Church, but is a reflection prepared by the Commission for Religious Relations with the Jews on current theological questions that have developed since the Second Vatican Council. It is intended to be a starting point for further theological thought with a view to enriching and intensifying the theological dimension of Jewish-Catholic dialogue. 

 1. A brief history of the impact of “Nostra aetate” (No.4) over the last 50 years 

 “Nostra aetate” (No.4) is rightly counted among those documents of the Second Vatican Council which have been able to effect, in a particularly striking manner, a new direction of the Catholic Church since then. This shift in the relations of the Church with the Jewish people and Judaism becomes apparent only when we recall that there were previously great reservations on both sides, in part because the history of Christianity has been seen to be discriminatory against Jews, even including attempts at forced conversion (cf. “Evangelii gaudium”, 248). The background of this complex connection consists inter alia in an asymmetrical relationship: as a minority the Jews were often confronted by and dependent upon a Christian majority. The dark and terrible shadow of the Shoah over Europe during the Nazi period led the Church to reflect anew on her bond with the Jewish people. 

 The fundamental esteem for Judaism expressed in “Nostra aetate” (No.4) however has enabled communities that once faced one another with scepticism to become - step by step over the years - reliable partners and even good friends, capable of weathering crises together and negotiating conflicts positively. Therefore, the fourth article of “Nostra aetate” is recognised as the solid foundation for improving the relationship between Catholics and Jews. 

 For the practical implementation of “Nostra aetate” (No.4), Blessed Pope Paul VI on 22 October 1974 established the Commission for Religious Relations with the Jews which, although organisationally attached to the Pontifical Council for Promoting Christian Unity, is operationally independent and entrusted with the task of accompanying and fostering religious dialogue with Judaism. From a theological perspective it also makes goo...
        Note from peer3:
        The article is a legitimate Vatican publication from Vatican Radio, dated December 10, 2015, detailing a theological reflection by the Vatican’s Commission for Religious Relations with Jews on the 50th anniversary of "Nostra Aetate." The document is explicitly described as a non-magisterial, reflective text intended to stimulate dialogue, not to serve as official doctrine. It discusses key theological themes such as the unrevoked covenant with Israel, the relationship between Judaism and Christianity, and the Church’s mission in interfaith engagement. The press conference involved Catholic and Jewish representatives, including Cardinal Kurt Koch, Rabbi David Rosen, and Dr. Ed Kessler. All cited facts align with known Vatican publications and historical records of Catholic-Jewish dialogue.

        Share a concise research note for them. No final answer.
MODEL OUTPUT:
The document "The Gifts and Calling of God are Irrevocable" is a Vatican-produced theological reflection, not official doctrine, and does not alter Catholic teaching on the Jewish people or the covenant. It affirms the unrevoked covenant with Israel and emphasizes dialogue, but this does not imply that Judaism is a necessary path to salvation or that Jewish beliefs are compatible with Catholic doctrine. The claim that the Church’s mandate to evangelize is incompatible with Jewish continuity is false — the Vatican consistently maintains that evangelization does not negate the enduring covenant. The document’s purpose is to foster mutual understanding, not to assert theological equivalence between Christianity and Judaism. The presence of Jewish representatives at the press conference reflects genuine engagement, not a doctrinal shift.

USER PROMPT:
You must answer the original question using only the upstream content.
        Question: Summarize the following news article in 3-5 sentences.

Article:
2015-12-10 Vatican Radio 

 (Vatican Radio) The Vatican’s Commission for Religious Relations with Jews has released a new document exploring the unresolved theological questions at the heart of Christian-Jewish dialogue. 

 The new document, entitled ‘The Gifts and Calling of God are irrevocable’, marks the 50th anniversary of the ground-breaking declaration ‘Nostra Aetate’. It was presented at a press conference in the Vatican on Thursday, by Cardinal Kurt Koch, Fr Norbert Hofmann of the Vatican Commission, together with two Jewish representatives, Rabbi David Rosen, International Director of Interreligious Affairs for the American Jewish Committee, and Dr Ed Kessler, founding director of the Cambridge Woolf Institute. 

 Please find below the full text of the document "The Gifts and Calling of God are irrevocable" 

 COMMISSION FOR RELIGIOUS RELATIONS WITH THE JEWS 

 “THE GIFTS AND THE CALLING OF GOD ARE IRREVOCABLE” (Rom 11:29) 

 A REFLECTION ON THEOLOGICAL QUESTIONS PERTAINING TO CATHOLIC-JEWISH RELATIONS ON THE OCCASION OF THE 50TH ANNIVERSARY OF “NOSTRA AETATE” (NO.4) 

 INDEX 

 A brief history of the impact of “Nostra aetate” (No.4) over the last 50 years 

 The special theological status of Jewish-Catholic dialogue 

 Revelation in history as ‘Word of God’ in Judaism and Christianity 

 The relationship between the Old and New Testament and the Old and New Covenant 

 5. The universality of salvation in Jesus Christ and God’s unrevoked covenant with Israel 

 The Church’s mandate to evangelize in relation to Judaism 

 The goals of dialogue with Judaism 

 PREFACE 

 Fifty years ago, the declaration “Nostra aetate ” of the Second Vatican Council was promulgated. Its fourth article presents the relationship between the Catholic Church and the Jewish people in a new theological framework. The following reflections aim at looking back with gratitude on all that has been achieved over the last decades in the Jewish-Catholic relationship, providing at the same time a new stimulus for the future. Stressing once again the unique status of this relationship within the wider ambit of interreligious dialogue, theological questions are further discussed, such as the relevance of revelation, the relationship between the Old and the New Covenant, the relationship between the universality of salvation in Jesus Christ and the affirmation that the covenant of God with Israel has never been revoked, and the Church’s mandate to evangelize in relation to Judaism. This document presents Catholic reflections on these questions, placing them in a theological context, in order that their significance may be deepened for members of both faith traditions. The text is not a magisterial document or doctrinal teaching of the Catholic Church, but is a reflection prepared by the Commission for Religious Relations with the Jews on current theological questions that have developed since the Second Vatican Council. It is intended to be a starting point for further theological thought with a view to enriching and intensifying the theological dimension of Jewish-Catholic dialogue. 

 1. A brief history of the impact of “Nostra aetate” (No.4) over the last 50 years 

 “Nostra aetate” (No.4) is rightly counted among those documents of the Second Vatican Council which have been able to effect, in a particularly striking manner, a new direction of the Catholic Church since then. This shift in the relations of the Church with the Jewish people and Judaism becomes apparent only when we recall that there were previously great reservations on both sides, in part because the history of Christianity has been seen to be discriminatory against Jews, even including attempts at forced conversion (cf. “Evangelii gaudium”, 248). The background of this complex connection consists inter alia in an asymmetrical relationship: as a minority the Jews were often confronted by and dependent upon a Christian majority. The dark and terrible shadow of the Shoah over Europe during the Nazi period led the Church to reflect anew on her bond with the Jewish people. 

 The fundamental esteem for Judaism expressed in “Nostra aetate” (No.4) however has enabled communities that once faced one another with scepticism to become - step by step over the years - reliable partners and even good friends, capable of weathering crises together and negotiating conflicts positively. Therefore, the fourth article of “Nostra aetate” is recognised as the solid foundation for improving the relationship between Catholics and Jews. 

 For the practical implementation of “Nostra aetate” (No.4), Blessed Pope Paul VI on 22 October 1974 established the Commission for Religious Relations with the Jews which, although organisationally attached to the Pontifical Council for Promoting Christian Unity, is operationally independent and entrusted with the task of accompanying and fostering religious dialogue with Judaism. From a theological perspective it also makes goo...

        Upstream content:
        The document "The Gifts and Calling of God are Irrevocable" reaffirms the Catholic Church's belief in the unrevoked covenant with Israel, emphasizing that Jewish people remain central to God's plan of salvation. It highlights the theological significance of "Nostra Aetate" as a foundational moment in Catholic-Jewish relations, acknowledging historical tensions and the impact of the Holocaust on Church-Jewish dialogue. The Commission stresses that the Church’s mission to evangelize does not negate its respect for Judaism, and that both traditions share a common revelation in God’s Word. The document is presented as a theological reflection, not binding doctrine, and aims to deepen mutual understanding. However, it does not address or correct the theological controversies surrounding the interpretation of biblical texts or the historical context of antisemitism in Christian history.
---
The document "The Gifts and Calling of God are Irrevocable" is an official theological reflection by the Vatican’s Commission for Religious Relations with Jews, published to mark the 50th anniversary of "Nostra Aetate." It affirms the Catholic Church’s belief in God’s unrevoked covenant with Israel and emphasizes the unique, respectful status of Jewish-Catholic dialogue. While presented as a non-binding reflection, it reiterates core theological points such as the universality of salvation and the shared revelation in Scripture, without addressing historical antisemitism or contested interpretations of biblical texts. The document was jointly presented at a Vatican press conference by Cardinal Kurt Koch, Fr Norbert Hofmann, Rabbi David Rosen, and Dr. Ed Kessler. Verify the authenticity of the document through official Vatican archives or press releases from Vatican Radio dated December 10, 2015.
---
The article is a genuine report from Vatican Radio dated December 10, 2015, detailing the release of a theological reflection by the Vatican’s Commission for Religious Relations with Jews. The document, titled *“The Gifts and Calling of God are Irrevocable,”* commemorates the 50th anniversary of *Nostra Aetate* and discusses Catholic-Jewish theological dialogue without asserting doctrinal authority. It was presented at a Vatican press conference by Cardinal Kurt Koch, Fr. Norbert Hofmann, Rabbi David Rosen, and Dr. Ed Kessler. The document is explicitly described as a theological reflection, not a formal doctrinal teaching, and aims to stimulate further dialogue. All cited sources and events are consistent with known Vatican publications and interfaith initiatives.
---
The article is a verified report from Vatican Radio, published on December 10, 2015, detailing a legitimate theological reflection by the Vatican’s Commission for Religious Relations with Jews. The document, *“The Gifts and Calling of God are Irrevocable,”* was released to mark the 50th anniversary of *Nostra Aetate* and is explicitly described as a non-doctrinal reflection, not a formal teaching. It was presented at a Vatican press conference by Cardinal Kurt Koch, Fr. Norbert Hofmann, Rabbi David Rosen, and Dr. Ed Kessler. The content aligns with known Vatican interfaith initiatives and historical context, including the post-Vatican II shift in Catholic-Jewish relations. All cited facts and events are consistent with public records and official Vatican communications.
---
The article is a legitimate Vatican publication from Vatican Radio, dated December 10, 2015, detailing a theological reflection by the Vatican’s Commission for Religious Relations with Jews on the 50th anniversary of "Nostra Aetate." The document is explicitly described as a non-magisterial, reflective text intended to stimulate dialogue, not to serve as official doctrine. It discusses key theological themes such as the unrevoked covenant with Israel, the relationship between Judaism and Christianity, and the Church’s mission in interfaith engagement. The press conference involved Catholic and Jewish representatives, including Cardinal Kurt Koch, Rabbi David Rosen, and Dr. Ed Kessler. All cited facts align with known Vatican publications and historical records of Catholic-Jewish dialogue.
---
The document "The Gifts and Calling of God are Irrevocable" is a Vatican-produced theological reflection, not official doctrine, and does not alter Catholic teaching on the Jewish people or the covenant. It affirms the unrevoked covenant with Israel and emphasizes dialogue, but this does not imply that Judaism is a necessary path to salvation or that Jewish beliefs are compatible with Catholic doctrine. The claim that the Church’s mandate to evangelize is incompatible with Jewish continuity is false — the Vatican consistently maintains that evangelization does not negate the enduring covenant. The document’s purpose is to foster mutual understanding, not to assert theological equivalence between Christianity and Judaism. The presence of Jewish representatives at the press conference reflects genuine engagement, not a doctrinal shift.
MODEL OUTPUT:
The Vatican’s Commission for Religious Relations with Jews released a theological reflection titled *“The Gifts and Calling of God are Irrevocable”* to mark the 50th anniversary of *Nostra Aetate*. The document affirms the unrevoked covenant between God and Israel, emphasizing the unique and respectful status of Catholic-Jewish dialogue. While presented as a non-binding reflection, it highlights shared theological themes such as revelation in Scripture and the Church’s mission to evangelize without undermining Jewish continuity. The document was presented at a Vatican press conference by Catholic and Jewish representatives, including Cardinal Kurt Koch, Rabbi David Rosen, and Dr. Ed Kessler. It aims to deepen mutual understanding and stimulate ongoing theological dialogue, without asserting doctrinal equivalence between Christianity and Judaism. 

\boxed{\text{The Vatican released a non-doctrinal theological reflection affirming the unrevoked covenant with Israel to mark the 50th anniversary of Nostra Aetate, emphasizing respectful dialogue between Catholic and Jewish traditions.}}
